Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This year 520 focused on the bandit problem, with an excellent overview of the research area and various critical papers and concepts.
The theory behind multi-arm bandit problems, and a good exposure to current research on related problems.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course is extremely strong and the content and teaching could use little in the way of improvement. The course was well organized and taught, and the material was interesting. The only "weakness" was the time of day - ending at 8pm is unfortunate.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. This class is excellent for any 2nd year graduate student looking to get a more thorough understanding of what micro theory research looks like. The topics change year to year, but if bandit algorithms are being taught again it's a fascinating topic to study with broad applicability and many avenues for research open. If you are not a 2nd year graduate student, I would also recommend this course to others with sufficient math background including analysis, econometrics (or statistics), and a bit of optimal control theory.

Its a course directed at students interested in pursuing research in game theory. It is intense in terms of how much you learn , so you should take it only if you really are interested in research in such a theoretical field.
